basics.name: Ignacio Laude
basics.label: Software Developer
basics.summary: I am a Sotware Engineer and a Hardware Hacker currently majoring in Mathematics and Computer Science. I expect to graduate in Spring, 2024. While my work focuses on Security Research and Software Development, mostly solving problems on a broad range of systems, from low latency trading engine to grid computing or embedded systems, I love joining CP competitions, you can check my old blog here, I love building custom keyboards and playing chess. My non-work interests range widely, everything from quantum computing, philosophy to chaos theory. I could tell you about it, but THAT would NOT be a “length-limited” conversation!.

highlights: Built a webhook that handles different endpoints which integrates existing systems for data collection and offer personalization based on geolocation using PHP and MySQL.
Built cross-platform mobile applications and web systems  for ride-hailing, courier delivery, and other transport-related services.
Identifying, documenting, and reporting vulnerabilities across many organizations and industries.

awards.title: 2021 Ateneo De Manila Senior High School Dagitab Programming Contest (Codeforces)
EO GSEA 2020 - 3rd Runner Up
awards.awarder: Entrepreneur's Organization - Global Student Entrepreneurship Awards
awards.summary: In recognition of my achievements as a student entrepreneur through the Entrepreneur's Organization - Global Student Entrepreneurship Awards.

awards.title: Security Researcher Acknowledgements for Microsoft Online Services

publications.name: Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI): Development of a BCI based on Motor Imagery with Advanced EEG Processing
publications.author: Ignacio Laude
publications.summary: Basically setting up a connection between the human brain and the computer device to control or to perform certain activity using brain signals.

publications.name: Basic Solutions to Quantum Mechanical Systems
publications.author: Ignacio Laude
publications.summary: This generic code solves for, and plots, the eigenfunctions and eigenvalues of a particle in a one-dimensional potential, based on the finite difference method code.
